hints.content: Start by understanding the requirement: you need to count elements that have both a strictly smaller and a strictly greater element in the array. Think about how you can identify these elements.

Consider the properties of the smallest and largest elements in the array. If you find the minimum and maximum values, any element that is equal to either of these cannot have both a smaller and a greater element.
You can use a set to track unique elements in the array. This will help you avoid counting duplicates when checking for strictly smaller and greater elements.
Once you have the unique elements, you can determine the smallest and largest values. This will allow you to easily filter out elements that do not meet the criteria.
Think about how you can iterate through the unique elements to check if each element has both a smaller and a greater element. You might want to use comparison operators for this.
Remember to handle edge cases, such as when the array has less than three unique elements. In such cases, the output should be 0 since no element can satisfy the condition.
Consider using a simple loop to count the valid elements after determining the min and max. For each unique element, check if it is greater than the minimum and less than the maximum.
You might want to use a counter variable to keep track of how many elements meet the criteria. Increment this counter whenever you find a valid element.
Before finalizing your solution, make sure to test it with various edge cases, such as arrays with all identical elements or arrays with negative and positive numbers.
To finalize your approach, structure your code to first extract unique elements, then find the min and max, and finally iterate through the unique elements to count how many meet the criteria.

questionNotes: Return the count of elements with both a strictly smaller and a strictly greater element.
Duplicates in the array should be counted if they meet the criteria.
